Problem:
We explore a physical system where a beam is subjected to various forces over time. The forces are represented as functions of time, \( f(t) \), acting at different points on the beam. Fourier transforms of these functions (\( F(\omega) \), where \( \omega \) is the frequency) are used to analyze the system's behavior in the frequency domain. The structural integrity response of the beam, \( R(\omega) \), depends on these inputs.

If an additional damping force proportional to velocity \( g(t) = -k\dot{x} \), where \( k \) is a constant, is introduced at \( t = t_1 \), will the frequency response \( R(\omega) \) at \( \omega = \omega_2 \) for \( \omega_2 \) still primarily reflect the influence of the original \( f(t) \)?
Explanation: The introduction of a damping force modifies the system dynamics significantly. The new force \( g(t) \) alters the system's impulse response, thereby influencing the resultant frequency response \( R(\omega) \). The response at \( \omega_2 \) will now reflect the composite effects of both \( f(t) \) and \( g(t) \), redistributing energy across the frequency spectrum.
